title: Hittin' Em With A Combo Move! - Headshot Photography Direction Tips
summary: Peter Hurley details his layered workflow for directing subjects during a headshot session. He explains how to combine verbal cues, specific hand gestures, and camera movements to efficiently position the head while keeping the subject relaxed and natural.

steps.action: Use the 'Suction Cup' visualization (hand on face) to explain how to tilt the head.
Apply the 'Karate Chop' hand gesture to indicate the specific angle of the face.
Use the 'Nose to Finger' technique, asking the subject to follow your finger with their nose for precise positioning.
Introduce 'Camera Prodding' (gesturing with the camera body) later in the shoot once the subject is comfortable with the flow.
Use a single focus point on the subject's front eye, then recompose the frame slightly if necessary.
Utilize verbal cues, such as 'nose to the window', to provide directional context.
Execute the full sequence: Start with verbal cues, move to hand gestures (Suction Cup/Karate Chop), and finish with Camera Prodding to maintain speed.

key_takeaways: Layer your direction techniques: start simple with verbal/hand cues and progress to camera prodding for efficiency.
Constant movement prevents the subject from overthinking their expression.
Camera prodding works best later in the session when a rhythm has been established.
Micro-adjustments in head angle can significantly impact the quality of the headshot.
